Award.AwardTitle: Building an Academic Pathway for the Aerial Sensing Data Analyst

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Sinclair Community College (Dayton, Ohio) and partners will fill a workforce need for data analysts working with data collected from remote sensors flown on unmanned aircraft. These individuals will be increasingly employed in the Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS)/Geospatial Intelligence Systems (GIS) sectors. Fueling the demand for Aerial Sensing Data Analysts are technological advances and the affordability and higher resolution of UAS compared to manned-aircraft and satellites. This project will develop a competency-based, hybrid post-secondary certificate for a new Aerial Data Sensing Analyst program to increase preparedness for entry-level employment in UAS/GIS, provide post-secondary professional development related to recruiting and retaining underrepresented populations, and conduct outreach and orientation activities for high school teachers and students regarding UAS/GIS educational pathways.

Due to an increasing number of civil and commercial applications for UAS/GIS methods, there is a growing demand for analysts who have the competencies needed to correct, calibrate, process, store, and analyze the numerous terabytes of data collected from UAS flight. This project will provide community college students an opportunity to master competencies in the growing field of UAS/GIS through the development of a new competency-based, online post-secondary certificate program, Aerial Sensing Data Analyst. The program also seeks to expand awareness of UAS/GIS careers and educational pathways among high school students and teachers, and increase the number of underserved students enrolled in targeted undergraduate programs, including military veterans who may have applicable prior experience for this growing commercial industry. In addition, the project will help advance understanding of how such competency-based certificate programs promote access to post-secondary opportunities, with attention to their influence on increasing recruitment and retention of students from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the "Building an Academic Pathway for the Aerial Sensing Data Analyst" project was to provide community college students, including underrepresented populations, an opportunity to master competencies in the growing Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) and Geospatial/Geographic Information Systems (GIS) fields of aerial sensing data analysis. The target populations were community college students who enrolled in a new Short-Term Technical Certificate (STTC) program and high school students, particularly female students, who participated in pipeline activities that stimulated interest in UAS/GIS careers.

The primary objectives were to:

  1. Increase community colleges’ capacity to meet emerging employer needs through a new competency-based, multi-disciplinary UAS/GIS certificate program that addresses a knowledge and skill gap
  2. Expand awareness of UAS/GIS careers and educational pathways among high school students and teachers
  3. Increase the number of female students enrolled in targeted undergraduate programs

A highly qualified team of Sinclair faculty members and external partners collaborated to accomplish four specific project goals including:

  1. Creation of a competency model for the Aerial Sensing Data Analyst occupation
  2. Development of a competency-based, hybrid certificate program for the aerial sensing data analyst
  3. Creation of recruitment and retention plans for underrepresented populations
  4. Conducting outreach activities to orient high school students and teachers to UAS/GIS career pathways

The project met or exceeded all planned goals, with notable highlights including:

Credit Program Creation, Pilot, and Refinement
During the project, 10 Competency-Based Education (CBE) courses were developed and piloted to create an Aerial Sensing Data Analyst (ASDA) certificate program at Sinclair College. Project goals for the total numbers of college students affected were exceeded through CBE courses with 65 individuals engaged in 134 CBE course enrollments. These enrollments reflected increases compared to the general UAS and Geospatial Technology (GST) Associate of Applied Science (AAS) degree programs, both of which now embed the certificate program as an option. For students in the ASDA STTC as compared to the broader degree programs, there was a 100% increase in female enrollment to 16% and a 33% increase in non-white students to 16%. The team also updated the labs in three non-ASDA STTC specific courses to ensure alignment of geospatial software versions across courses for students that elected to pursue the GST AAS degree following completion of the ASDA STTC program.

STEM Outreach
Project goals for individual students and faculty affected by project materials and increased awareness of aerial sensing data analysis academic options and career paths were significantly exceeded. During the middle and high school outreach phase conducted by the project team, at least 2,069 pre-college students were reached, plus an additional 283 students reached by teachers piloting STEM content developed under the project. It is estimated that at least 45 middle and high school teachers were engaged through an Institute for Women in Trades, Technology and Science (IWITTS) training, STEM content training, and direct school outreach and instructional activities delivered by project staff and partners. New STEM content created under the project, now available for free on the Dayton Regional STEM Center website, included lesson plans, activities, and videos highlighting UAS and aerial sensing data analysis related applications and careers. This effort has resulted in significant interest in aerial sensing data analysis as a career and academic path, which is expected to result in increased enrollment and program growth in future years as these students graduate high school and choose their college areas of study.

Distribution and Dissemination
Significant efforts were given to broad project distribution, dissemination, and awareness. During the project, many presentations about the activities and results were given at venues including the Unmanned Systems Academic Summit, East Lakes Division of the American Association of Geographers conference, NSF ATE PI Conference, NSF Center for UAS Industry Advisory Board meeting, USGIF Accredited Academic Programs Summit, and Annual American Association of Geographers conference, among other opportunities, reaching an estimated combined total of over 350 professional conference attendees.

In summary, the project addressed all stated objectives, and significantly exceeded the goals of numbers of individuals positively affected.


Last Modified: 10/28/2019
Modified by: Andrew D Shepherd
